abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Economic Modernization Loan (EML) to
            Guatemala. The Government launched a program to stabilize
            the economy and lay the basis for medium-term growth, and
            requested assistance from the Bank in the form of a
            structural adjustment loan to support its economic program.
            The key objectives of the program were to: (i) strengthen
            public finances through the implementation of a
            comprehensive tax package and reform of tax and customs
            administration; (ii) improve public enterprise efficiency;
            (iii) further liberalize trade; (iv) promote financial
            sector reform through restructuring public banks and
            improving prudential regulations and bank supervision; and
            (v) intensify efforts to alleviate poverty by increasing
            allocations to basic health and education services. Overall
            Bank performance in the EML is assessed as satisfactory.
            Borrower performance in terms of identification,
            implementation and covenant compliance was satisfactory. The
            most important lessons learned are: (i) design of reform
            programs in countries without prior experience with
            Bank-supported adjustment operations should aim for
            simplicity and compactness; (ii)a realistic assessment of
            the Borrower's institutional capacity is critical to
            the success of a structural adjustment program; (iii)
            effective coordination with other co financiers should also
            be promoted to help prevent lack of coherence in the
            conditionality design; (iv) the legal department should be
            involved from the outset to enable it to examine and
            consider alternative legal approaches, if any, to achieve
            the desired objectives; and (v)while specificity is
            essential to avoid ambiguity with respect to adjustment loan
            conditionalities, some flexibility is also called for.
